tossups.question: One of these things is described as "upright and ablaze" in a poem about someone first beginning to read. In one poem, a person is instructed to tell one of these things about "the world, not the indescribable." One poem calls these things "almost deadly birds of the soul" when asking about the days of Tobias. One poetic depiction of these things was based around hearing a sound in a storm at a (*) castle on the Adriatic Coast owned by Marie von Thurn-und-Taxis. That poem says that "every [one of these things] is terrifying." The question "but who, if I cried out, would hear me among" the orders of these beings opens Rainer Maria Rilke's Duino Elegies. For 10 points, name these heavenly beings often described as having wings in Christian literature.
tossups.answer: angels [Note: the first clue is from Mohammed's Summoning, the rest are from the Duino Elegies]
tossups.answer_formatted: angels [Note: the first clue is from Mohammed's Summoning, the rest are from the Duino Elegies]

tossups.question: Enzymes that act on this ion are associated with proline-rich box1 and box2 regions. It's not bicarbonate, but this ion is the basis for the only buffer system in the body that is present in every cell. This ion is usually attached to serine or threonine residues, and it is added to tyrosine residues by RTKs. This anion is attached by the F0 subunit of one enzyme. The (*) "pyro" type of this anion is cleaved by adenylyl cyclase. Kinases add this anion to molecules. This anion is added to molecules in the electron transport chain in a namesake oxidative process. A sugar, nitrogenous base, and this anion are present in a nucleotide. For 10 points, name this anion, three of which are attached to adenosine in ATP.
tossups.answer: phosphate [or PO4 3-; accept oxidative phosphorylation; accept pyrophosphate] [the first clue refers to the Janus kinase]
tossups.answer_formatted: phosphate [the first clue refers to the Janus kinase] [or PO4 3-; accept oxidative phosphorylation; accept pyrophosphate]
acceptable: phosphate [the first clue refers to the Janus kinase]
phosphate [the first clue refers to the Janus kinase]

tossups.question: To prove they were not protected by black magic, one leader of this country sipped beer as another leader's ear was cut off. The People's Redemption Council was established in this country after members of the True Whig party, including William Tobert, were executed. Prince Johnson, a leader of this country, tortured and   executed Samuel Doe. It's not the USA, but this country includes Maryland county. After this country's second civil war, Charles (*) Taylor was removed as the president of this country. The first elected female head of state, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, led this country for 12 years. The American Colonization society populated this country. For 10 points, name this African country with a capital at Monrovia that was founded by former slaves.

A former companion of this character joins a law firm in Franz Kafka's short story "The New Advocate." In some stories, this character, whose father may be Nectanebo, is stuck in a diving bell when his lover eloped with another. A "Romance" named for this member of the Nine Worthies is legendarily attributed to the historian Callisthenes. This man, who is credited with introducing the custom of (*) proskynesis, may have been the son of Zeus and his mother Olympias, but was almost certainly born in Pella. The Gordian Knot was cut by this mythological figure, who was also the recipient of a supposed letter from his tutor Aristotle. This figure's namesake romance says that his horse Bucephalus surpassed Pegasus. For 10 points, what son of Philip the Great conquered much of Greece and Asia?

Every tournament contains a construct named for this mathematician by Redei's theorem. The Bondy-Chvatal lemma gives a criterion for a property named for this mathematician, who devised the icosian game. By a result of Dirac, a n-vertex graph has that property named for this mathematician if each vertex has degree at least n/2. This mathematician is second in the name of a theorem that states that every (*) square matrix satisfies its characteristic polynomial. The 3D cross product is equivalent to multiplication in a ring devised by this mathematician, explaining its usage to model rotations in computer graphics. Constructs named for this mathematician, exemplified by knight's tours, visit every vertex of a graph exactly once and are contrasted with Eulerian cycles. For 10 points, name this Irish mathematician who developed quaternions.

Description acceptable. Joe Fassler wrote a piece collecting authors' recommendations of these texts after being asked to do so by Stephen King in an Atlantic interview. One of these texts which describes how "the rain fell in torrents" before explaining "(for it is in London that our scene lies)" is found in the book Paul Clifford. A yearly prize given to one of these works is named for Edward (*) Bulwer-Lytton. Papal bulls are titled for parts of these texts. One of these texts reads "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife", while a cliched one is "It was a dark and stormy night." For 10 points, name these sentences which open novels.
tossups.answer: first sentences [accept opening sentences or opening lines or first lines; accept incipit; prompt on start or beginning; prompt on novels or books with "what part?"; prompt on sentence]
tossups.answer_formatted: first sentences [accept opening sentences or opening lines or first lines; accept incipit; prompt on start or beginning; prompt on novels or books with "what part?; prompt on sentence]

tossups.question: Paris Green was used to stop the destruction of this commodity after its earlier use as a paint. Antoine-Augustin Parmentier increased French production of this commodity after he convinced Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette to wear some of it. This commodity is stored by being turned into chuño. P. infestans has caused many issues afflicting this commodity, such as a time in which Charles Trevelyan tried to avoid giving aid to people for whom this crop had failed. A lack of this crop gave rise to the souperism charity and missionary movement; that same decline in production of this crop led to the repeal of the Corn Laws by Robert Peel. This crop was first produced in the Andes, where it is often found in blue and purple varieties. For 10 points, name this crop that names a famine which afflicted Ireland.

bonuses.leadin: Alcanivorax borkumensis is a bacterium that proliferates during these events because it can feed off a product of these events. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these events where a certain fossil fuel is released, generally into the ocean. Examples of these include Deepwater Horizon.

This type of chemical is often used to respond to an oil spill, such as when one of these, Corexit, was used on the Deepwater Horizon spill. They decrease the chance of oil slicks on seashores but likely harm underwater environments.

This other oil spill used skimming to successfully remove some oil, although attempts to blast oil off the shore with high-pressure water were damaging to the coast. This second-largest American oil spill led to double hulls being mandated for many oil transport vessels.
answers: dispersant [prompt on surfactant or dispersing agent; prompt on detergent]

bonuses.leadin: Margherita Beloch's work in a field of mathematics studying this practice led her to devise a way of solving cubic equations based on Lill's method. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this practice, governed by a set of axioms named for Huzita and Justin. This practice is the Japanese art of paper-folding.

The first five Huzita-Justin axioms are sufficient for one to obtain the set of numbers that possess this property via origami. Gauss proved that the regular 17-gon possesses this property, but the regular heptagon does not. Again, a description is fine.

Proving the Gauss-Wantzel theorem, which gives a characterization of all constructible polynomials, requires one to prove that the Euler totient of these primes is a power of two. A description isn't fine this time.
answers: constructible [accept descriptions indicating that they can be constructed with compass and straightedge, do not accept any answer that mentions "rulers" as that's completely different]
answers_formatted: constructible [accept descriptions indicating that they can be constructed with compass or straightedge, do not or any answer that mentions "rulers" as that's completely different]
acceptable: descriptions indicating that they can be constructed with compass
any answer that mentions "rulers" as that's completely different

bonuses.leadin: Tertiary carbocations can be stabilized by neighboring alkyl groups through this effect. For 10 points each:
parts: Electronegative groups can pull electron density through sigma bonds in this effect, leading to the formation of a dipole moment.
Substitution reactions that have this overall reaction order often feature a carbocation intermediate. Reactions with this order have a constant half-life.
Carbocations are characterized by carbon having this type of charge. An atom that loses an electron will have this kind of charge.
answers: one [accept SN1 or unimolecular or first order]

bonuses.leadin: Name some information about this famous Roman orator who was born in Arpinum, for 10 points each:
parts: This orator spoke out against Caesar when Caesar declared himself emperor and was known as the greatest Roman orator of the late Roman Republic. His name derives from the Latin for "chickpea" and his head and hands were pinned to the Rostra following his assassination.

Cicero uncovered the plot of one of these events after receiving information from the mistress of this event's lead member, which aimed to assassinate members of the Senate. One of these events occurred after the lead member of it was rejected from consulship.

This speech was delivered by Cicero in defense of a man who supported Catiline. It claimed that the prosecution was prosecuting on account of his youth and blamed his misguided judgment on the wickedness of Catiline. It attacked noblewoman Clodia for lying about the man accused of poisoning her.
answers: Pro Caelio [accept In Defense of Caelius]

bonuses.leadin: This author's novel A Man Asleep, paired in translation with Things, uses second-person to vividly illustrate a deep depression. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author. This author worked the protagonist of A Man Asleep into the character of Gregoire Simpson, who is described in Chapter 52 of this author's Oulipian magnum opus Life, A User's Manual.
A Man Asleep takes its title from a passage in this French author's novel Swann's Way, the first part of In Search of Lost Time.

In claiming that "Indifference is futile," the narrator of A Man Asleep compares himself to this ship, noting that "there was no devious-cruising Rachel to rescue you." In another novel, a survivor of the wreck of this ship is found floating on a coffin.
answers: Georges Perec [yes, the A Void guy]
the Pequod [prompt on anything indicating the ship from Moby Dick]
answers_formatted: the Pequod [prompt on anything indicating the ship from Moby Dick]
promptable: anything indicating the ship from Moby Dick
